awd_titl_txt: Conference: Number Theory and Combinatorics in Duluth
awd_abstract_narration:
The Number Theory and Combinatorics in Duluth Conference will be held at the University of Minnesota, Duluth, from July 31 to August 4, 2023. The goal of this conference is to bring together people of all career stages, from students to internationally recognized experts, who are studying topics in combinatorics and number theory from various overlapping perspectives. This conference will feature invited talks by researchers working at the forefront of their fields as well as contributed talks and 5-minute lightning talk sessions, which will enable every participant to speak. Mathematicians from underrepresented demographics, early career researchers, and researchers from non-R1 institutions are especially encouraged to attend to ensure a broad exchange of knowledge and perspectives.

Combinatorics and number theory have been historically interconnected in a variety of ways and have been central in both answering many classical questions and leading to new research directions. Examples include the Gauss circle problem, generating functions, representations of integers as sums of squares and Jacobi's formulas, the partition function, and the work of Ramanujan. These connections have been especially prominent in recent years, particularly due to the extensive use of tools from one area to the benefit of the other. This conference will bring together a wide variety of researchers, and the format of the conference has been designed to give all participants the opportunity to speak to facilitate the exchange of ideas and to encourage collaboration. The conference website can be found at https://sites.google.com/d.umn.edu/gallianfest/home.

This conference is supported by the Algebra and Number Theory and Combinatorics programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the "Number theory and Combinatorics in Duluth" conference which took place July 31-August 4 on the campus of University of Minnesota Duluth.  Over 120 registered participants registered for this conference. The conference featured hour-long invited talks by 16 preeminent mathematicians as well as 16 half hour-long contributed talks. In addition, the conference had two sessions of 5-minute lightning talks where all participants were encouraged to discuss their research.  The award supported participant travel and accommodation. 

The goal of the conference was to expose the interconnectivity of number theory and combinatorics to a wide range of researchers. These two fields have a rich history with deep and meaningful connections which has driven both fields for more than one hundred years.  By bringing together both experienced researches as well as students and early career mathematicians, we have encouraged and facilitated the formation of new and exciting future connections.

The conference was widely advertised to promote a diverstity of representation amongst the participants. The format comprsing of contributed and lightning talks was purposefully designed to provide an inclusive environment of collaboration and sharing for researchers from underrepresented groups, students and early career mathematicians, as well as researchers from liberal arts and non R1-universities.  


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Kathleen L Petersen
